https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=713643
This follow-up bug suggests that the changes in the -moz-border-image implementation will be reverted for the FF 12 stable release. Instead, the unprefixed border-image property will be supported with the same syntax as -moz-border-image in FF 12 Aurora, which is based on the current CSS Borders and Backgrounds spec draft:
http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css3-background/#border-images

The change was backed out of Aurora, which now once again only supports MozBorderImage with the non-standard syntax. However, after removing the workaround implemented for bug #5116, our CSS style detection prefers non-prefixed properties if both variants are supported (as in recent WebKit browsers), so I implemented a detection routine for the supported syntax. The result is available via the "css.borderimage.standardsyntax" environment key and ui.decoration.css3.BorderImage.getMarkup adjusts the borderImage value accordingly. (4e9d9513 on master, 9f5827e0 on branch_1_6_x)
Additionally, as pointed out by Ralf Kornmann on the mailing list, Gecko no longer implies "border-style: solid" when border image is used. BorderImage.getMarkup now sets this as well. (d64a8081 on master, e3564b28 on branch_1_6_x)
Closed all bugs already shipped with a release.
